title: Paul's Journey to Rome
shortSummary: Acts 28 recounts Paul's shipwreck on the island of Melita, his miraculous healing ministry there, and his eventual arrival in Rome. The chapter highlights God's providential care, the spread of the Gospel to the Gentiles, and Paul's bold witness under house arrest. It marks the transition of the Gospel reaching the heart of the Roman Empire.
timeline: c. AD 60 - Paul's Journey to Rome and Imprisonment

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and missionary who, despite shipwreck and imprisonment, faithfully preaches the kingdom of God and the Lord Jesus Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Publius
keyCharacters.description: The chief man of the island Melita who hospitably receives Paul and is healed by him.

keyCharacters.name: Centurion
keyCharacters.description: The Roman officer responsible for Paul and the prisoners, who allows Paul to live under guarded freedom in Rome.

keyCharacters.name: Chief of the Jews
keyCharacters.description: Jewish leaders in Rome whom Paul calls to explain his situation and to witness about Jesus.

definitions.definition: The island where Paul was shipwrecked, traditionally identified with modern Malta.
A venomous snake that bit Paul, symbolizing danger and God's protection when Paul was unharmed.
An ancient term for dysentery or severe intestinal bleeding, a serious illness healed by Paul.
The twin gods of sailors in Greco-Roman mythology, whose sign was on the ship that carried Paul from Melita.
A term used by Jews to describe the Christian movement, often with suspicion or hostility.

outline.heading: Paul Shipwrecked on Melita and Miraculous Healing
outline.description: After surviving a shipwreck, Paul and others are welcomed by the islanders of Melita. Paul is bitten by a viper but suffers no harm, leading the islanders to regard him as a god. Paul heals Publius' father and many others, demonstrating God's power and grace.

outline.heading: Paul's Journey from Melita to Rome
outline.description: Paul departs Melita on a ship bound for Rome, stopping at various ports where he is warmly received by fellow believers. Upon arrival in Rome, Paul is placed under guarded house arrest but allowed to live independently.

outline.heading: Paul's Defense and Ministry in Rome
outline.description: Paul calls the Jewish leaders in Rome to explain his case and testify about Jesus. Some believe, others reject the message, fulfilling Isaiahâ€™s prophecy about hardened hearts. Paul preaches boldly for two years, teaching about the kingdom of God with confidence despite his imprisonment.

application: Trust in God's providential care even in life-threatening circumstances, as Paul experienced on Melita.
Be bold and faithful in sharing the Gospel regardless of opposition or personal hardship.
Show hospitality and kindness to those who minister God's healing and truth, following the example of the islanders and brethren.
Continue steadfastly in prayer and teaching, knowing that God can use even imprisonment to advance His kingdom.

keyVerses.text: Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's supernatural protection over Paul, affirming his divine mission despite hostile circumstances.

keyVerses.text: Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and that they will hear it.
keyVerses.significance: Paul declares the pivotal truth that God's salvation extends to the Gentiles, marking a major theme of the book of Acts.

keyVerses.text: And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him, Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all confidence, no man forbidding him.
keyVerses.significance: These verses conclude Acts by showing Paul's unwavering commitment to preaching the Gospel boldly, even while under house arrest.
